questions.text: True about insulinoma is:

options.label: D
options.text: It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C-peptide level is elevated

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Alpha cell tumor: This is incorrect; insulinomas arise from beta cells of the pancreas , which are responsible for the production of insulin.
  • • Option A:
  • • Alpha cell tumor:
  • • insulinomas arise from beta cells
  • • pancreas
  • • Option B: Most of them are malignant: The majority of insulinomas are benign ; only a small percentage are malignant.
  • • Option B:
  • • Most of them are malignant:
  • • majority of insulinomas are benign
  • • Option D: It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome : This is incorrect; insulinomas can be associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 .
  • • Option D:
  • • It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome
  • • insulinomas
  • • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulinomas are beta-cell tumors , most of which are benign and can present with hypoglycemia and elevated levels of insulin and C-peptide in the blood . They may also be associated with MEN 1 syndrome .
  • ➤ Insulinomas
  • ➤ beta-cell tumors
  • ➤ benign
  • ➤ present with hypoglycemia
  • ➤ elevated levels of insulin
  • ➤ C-peptide in the blood
  • ➤ MEN 1 syndrome
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1124
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1124

questions.text: Fine needle aspiration cytology is not able to detect which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Follicular cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma: FNAC is usually diagnostic for papillary carcinoma due to its distinctive cytological features , including nuclear grooves and psammoma bodies .
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma:
  • • FNAC
  • • diagnostic for papillary carcinoma
  • • distinctive cytological features
  • • nuclear grooves
  • • psammoma bodies
  • • Option B: Hashimoto thyroiditis: FNAC can suggest this diagnosis when lymphocytes and Hurthle cells are present , indicating an autoimmune process .
  • • Option B:
  • • Hashimoto thyroiditis:
  • • diagnosis when lymphocytes
  • • Hurthle cells are present
  • • autoimmune process
  • • Option D: Medullary cancer: FNAC can suggest medullary carcinoma by demonstrating amyloid and calcitonin in cells , but a definitive diagnosis often requires additional tests such as serum calcitonin levels.
  • • Option D:
  • • Medullary cancer:
  • • FNAC
  • • medullary carcinoma
  • • demonstrating amyloid
  • • calcitonin in cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While FNAC is a useful tool in the initial assessment of thyroid nodules, it cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma due to the necessity of examining capsular and vascular invasion histologically.
  • ➤ FNAC is a useful tool
  • ➤ initial assessment of thyroid nodules,
  • ➤ cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma
  • ➤ follicular carcinoma
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1089
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th 1089

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma of colon

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid: It is known to frequently have psammoma bodies , which are calcified concentric structures found within the tumor tissue.
  • • Option A:
  • • Papillary carcinoma of thyroid:
  • • frequently have psammoma bodies
  • • calcified concentric structures
  • • Option C: Meningioma: This benign brain tumor often contains psammoma bodies , contributing to its classic histological appearance .
  • • Option C:
  • • Meningioma:
  • • benign brain tumor
  • • psammoma bodies
  • • classic histological appearance
  • • Option D: Papillary cancer of the ovary (serous cystadenoma of the ovary): Similar to papillary thyroid carcinoma , ovarian papillary tumors can also exhibit psammoma bodies .
  • • Option D:
  • • Papillary cancer of the ovary (serous cystadenoma of the ovary):
  • • papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • • ovarian papillary tumors
  • • exhibit psammoma bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psammoma bodies are calcified structures often found in certain neoplasms such as papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, meningioma , and papillary cancer of the ovary (serous cystadenoma of the ovary) but are not typically seen in adenocarcinoma of the colon .
  • ➤ Psammoma bodies
  • ➤ calcified structures
  • ➤ found in certain neoplasms
  • ➤ papillary carcinoma
  • ➤ thyroid, meningioma
  • ➤ papillary cancer of the ovary
  • ➤ adenocarcinoma of the colon
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1098
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1098

questions.text: Necrobiosis lipoidica is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diabetes mellitus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Diabetes insipidus: This is a condition characterized by polyuria and polydipsia due to issues with vasopressin (ADH); it is not associated with skin changes like necrobiosis lipoidica.
  • • Option A: Diabetes insipidus:
  • • polyuria and polydipsia
  • • issues with vasopressin
  • • Option B: Lyme disease : Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted by ticks , Lyme disease can present with a variety of symptoms including erythema migrans, but not necrobiosis lipoidica.
  • • Option B: Lyme disease
  • • Borrelia burgdorferi
  • • transmitted by ticks
  • • Lyme disease
  • • Option D: Simmonds disease: Also known as Sheehan's syndrome , is postpartum hypopituitarism , not associated with necrobiosis lipoidica.
  • • Option D: Simmonds disease:
  • • Sheehan's syndrome
  • • postpartum hypopituitarism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Necrobiosis lipoidica is a skin condition primarily associated with diabetes mellitus , presenting as well-circumscribed, waxy plaques typically on the shins with a yellowish center and telangiectatic borders .
  • ➤ Necrobiosis lipoidica
  • ➤ skin condition
  • ➤ diabetes mellitus
  • ➤ well-circumscribed, waxy plaques
  • ➤ shins
  • ➤ yellowish center
  • ➤ telangiectatic borders

questions.text: Mauriac’s syndrome is characterized by all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardiomegaly

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Diabetes: Mauriac's syndrome is specifically associated with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus in children .
  • • Option A: Diabetes:
  • • Mauriac's syndrome
  • • poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus
  • • children
  • • Option B: Obesity: Despite being a sign of poor glycemic control , obesity is not a characteristic of Mauriac's syndrome . Instead, patients may present with Cushingoid features.
  • • Option B: Obesity:
  • • sign of poor glycemic control
  • • obesity
  • • not
  • • Mauriac's syndrome
  • • Option C: Dwarfism: Growth impairment or stunted growth is a classical component of Mauriac's syndrome due to chronic hyperglycemia and its metabolic effects.
  • • Option C: Dwarfism:
  • • Growth impairment
  • • stunted growth
  • • classical component of Mauriac's syndrome
  • • chronic hyperglycemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mauriac's syndrome is associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus in children and presents with hepatomegaly , growth retardation , and Cushingoid features , but not with cardiomegaly.
  • ➤ Mauriac's syndrome
  • ➤ type 1 diabetes mellitus
  • ➤ children
  • ➤ hepatomegaly
  • ➤ growth retardation
  • ➤ Cushingoid features

questions.text: What is the primary contributor to insulin resistance in liver disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Steatosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Decreased insulin release: This refers to a problem with insulin secretion from the pancreas , not resistance at the level of hepatic or peripheral tissues and does not directly relate to liver disease.
  • • Option A: Decreased insulin release:
  • • problem with insulin secretion
  • • pancreas
  • • Option C: Hepatocyte dysfunction: While hepatocyte dysfunction can contribute to metabolic disturbances , it is a broader term that includes various liver impairments, not specific to insulin resistance.
  • • Option C:
  • • Hepatocyte dysfunction:
  • • hepatocyte dysfunction
  • • metabolic disturbances
  • • Option D: Decreased ‘C’ peptide level: C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production . Lower levels may indicate reduced insulin secretion but are not a direct cause of insulin resistance in the liver.
  • • Option D:
  • • Decreased ‘C’ peptide level:
  • • C-peptide
  • • byproduct of insulin production
  • • Lower levels
  • • reduced insulin secretion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatic steatosis , or fatty liver disease , is a significant contributor to insulin resistance , which impairs both the liver's response to insulin and the peripheral action of insulin .
  • ➤ Hepatic steatosis
  • ➤ fatty liver disease
  • ➤ contributor to insulin resistance
  • ➤ impairs both the liver's response
  • ➤ insulin
  • ➤ peripheral action of insulin
  • ➤ Ref : Robbin 10th/ 1140, Joslin’s Diabetes Mellitus 14/e p436
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbin 10th/ 1140, Joslin’s Diabetes Mellitus 14/e p436

questions.text: According to ADA guidelines, the diagnosis of diabetes is made when the fasting blood glucose is more than?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 126 mg/dL

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: 100 mg/dL: This is considered the upper limit of normal for fasting glucose , with levels between 100 mg/dL and 125 mg/dL indicating impaired fasting glucose or prediabetes.
  • • Option B:
  • • 100 mg/dL:
  • • upper limit of normal for fasting glucose
  • • levels between 100 mg/dL
  • • 125 mg/dL
  • • impaired fasting glucose
  • • Option C: 140 mg/dL: This level is above the diagnostic criteria for diabetes when measured fasting and may also indicate diabetes if it is a 2-hour postprandial or oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) value.
  • • Option C:
  • • 140 mg/dL:
  • • above the diagnostic criteria
  • • diabetes
  • • measured fasting
  • • indicate diabetes
  • • Option D: 200 mg/dL: A level of 200 mg/dL or higher may indicate diabetes if it is from a random plasma glucose test accompanied by classic symptoms of hyperglycemia or hyperglycemic crisis, or during an OGTT.
  • • Option D:
  • • 200 mg/dL:
  • • level of 200 mg/dL
  • • higher
  • • diabetes
  • • random plasma glucose test
  • • classic symptoms
  • • hyperglycemia
  • • hyperglycemic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes mellitus according to ADA guidelines .
  • ➤ fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL
  • ➤ higher
  • ➤ diabetes mellitus
  • ➤ ADA guidelines
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th /1110
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th /1110

questions.text: Most common association in MEN I is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gastrinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Insulinoma: Insulinomas are also associated with MEN I and result in hypoglycemia due to unregulated insulin secretion , but they are less common compared to gastrinomas.
  • • Option B: Insulinoma:
  • • associated with MEN I
  • • hypoglycemia
  • • unregulated insulin secretion
  • • less common
  • • Option C: Lipoma : While patients with MEN I may develop non-endocrine tumors like lipomas , these are not as commonly associated with the syndrome as endocrine tumors.
  • • Option C:
  • • Lipoma
  • • MEN I may develop non-endocrine tumors
  • • lipomas
  • • Option D: Glucagonoma : Glucagonomas, which secrete glucagon , are rare pancreatic endocrine tumors and are less commonly associated with MEN I than gastrinomas.
  • • Option D:
  • • Glucagonoma
  • • secrete glucagon
  • • rare pancreatic endocrine tumors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of MEN I , gastrinomas are the most commonly associated functional pancreatic endocrine tumors , often leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome , characterized by peptic ulcer disease , gastroesophageal reflux , and diarrhea due to hypergastrinemia .
  • ➤ MEN I
  • ➤ gastrinomas
  • ➤ most commonly associated functional pancreatic endocrine tumors
  • ➤ Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • ➤ peptic ulcer disease
  • ➤ gastroesophageal reflux
  • ➤ diarrhea
  • ➤ hypergastrinemia
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1140
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1140

questions.text: What marker is indicative of a non-functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chromogranin-A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: CD100: CD100 is not a recognized marker for PNETs . CD markers are generally used in the characterization of lymphocytes and other cells of the immune system.
  • • Option B:
  • • CD100:
  • • not a recognized marker for PNETs
  • • Option C: CEA: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker associated with colorectal cancer and some other adenocarcinomas, not specifically with PNETs.
  • • Option C:
  • • CEA:
  • • tumor marker associated with colorectal cancer
  • • Option D: PSA: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is used as a marker for prostate cancer . It has no relevance in the diagnosis of PNETs.
  • • Option D: PSA:
  • • marker for prostate cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromogranin A is a marker for pancreatic non-functional neuroendocrine tumours .
  • ➤ Chromogranin A
  • ➤ marker for pancreatic non-functional neuroendocrine tumours
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 720
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th 720

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral lower extremity swelling and fatigue for the past several months. He has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and obesity. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum creatinine and proteinuria. A renal biopsy is performed, which demonstrates deposition of amyloid proteins in the glomeruli. Which of the following types of diabetes mellitus is most commonly associated with this renal complication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type II DM

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is characterized by monogenic defects of β-cell function but is not typically associated with amyloid deposition in the islets.
  • • Option A:
  • • Maturity onset diabetes of the young
  • • monogenic defects of β-cell function
  • • Option B: Type I DM is an autoimmune disorder leading to β-cell destruction and does not typically involve amyloid deposition.
  • • Option B:
  • • Type I DM
  • • autoimmune disorder
  • • β-cell destruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amyloid deposition in the islets of Langerhans is a feature specifically associated with Type II diabetes mellitus , which can contribute to the dysfunction of insulin-secreting pancreatic β-cells .
  • ➤ Amyloid deposition
  • ➤ islets of Langerhans
  • ➤ Type II diabetes mellitus
  • ➤ dysfunction of insulin-secreting pancreatic β-cells
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 261
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 261

questions.text: Which of the following thyroid carcinoma variants is not associated with aggressiveness?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Follicular variant

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: Unencapsulated: Lack of encapsulation is a feature associated with increased aggressiveness in papillary carcinoma . Encapsulation can help contain the tumor and prevent its spread . So, this option matches the criteria for aggressiveness.
  • • Option B: Unencapsulated:
  • • Lack of encapsulation
  • • increased aggressiveness in papillary carcinoma
  • • Encapsulation
  • • contain the tumor
  • • prevent its spread
  • • Option C: Tall cell variant: The tall cell variant of papillary carcinoma is associated with a more aggressive behavior compared to classical papillary carcinoma . Therefore, this option matches the criteria for aggressiveness.
  • • Option C: Tall cell variant:
  • • papillary carcinoma
  • • more aggressive behavior
  • • classical papillary carcinoma
  • • Option D: Oxyphilic (Hurthle) cell type: Hurthle cell carcinoma, a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma , is generally considered more aggressive than papillary carcinoma.
  • • Option D: Oxyphilic (Hurthle) cell type:
  • • variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The f ollicular variant of papillary carcinoma tends to have a better prognosis compared to classical papillary carcinoma as it is less aggressive in its behavior .
  • ➤ f
  • ➤ ollicular variant of papillary carcinoma
  • ➤ better prognosis
  • ➤ classical papillary carcinoma
  • ➤ less aggressive in its behavior
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1091
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1091

questions.text: Which of the following thyroid carcinomas originates from C-cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B: Follicular carcinoma: This carcinoma arises from follicular cells , which are responsible for synthesizing and secreting thyroid hormones , not calcitonin.
  • • Option B:
  • • Follicular carcinoma:
  • • carcinoma arises from follicular cells
  • • synthesizing
  • • secreting thyroid hormones
  • • Option C: Papillary carcinoma: The most common type of thyroid cancer , also derived from follicular cells , and not from C-cells.
  • • Option C:
  • • Papillary carcinoma:
  • • common type of thyroid cancer
  • • follicular cells
  • • Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma: A rare and highly aggressive thyroid cancer that arises from follicular cells and has a poor prognosis ; it does not originate from C-cells.
  • • Option D:
  • • Anaplastic carcinoma:
  • • rare and highly aggressive thyroid cancer
  • • arises from follicular cells
  • • has a poor prognosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is derived from C-cells , which are distinct from follicular cells that give rise to the more common papillary and follicular thyroid carcinomas . Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by the production of calcitonin and may be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2).
  • ➤ Medullary carcinoma
  • ➤ thyroid is derived from C-cells
  • ➤ distinct from follicular cells
  • ➤ rise to the more common papillary
  • ➤ follicular thyroid carcinomas
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ production of calcitonin
  • ➤ multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1095
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1095

questions.text: Hurthle cell tumor is:

options.label: D
options.text: Ionizing radiation in early decades is a major risk factor

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Follicular carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma – This is the most common type of thyroid carcinoma , but Hurthle cell tumors are not classified as papillary carcinoma.
  • • Option A:
  • • Papillary carcinoma
  • • thyroid carcinoma
  • • Hurthle cell tumors
  • • papillary carcinoma.
  • • Option C: Medullary carcinoma – This type arises from parafollicular C cells , which is not related to the follicular cells that give rise to Hurthle cell tumors .
  • • Option C:
  • • Medullary carcinoma
  • • arises from parafollicular C cells
  • • not related to the follicular cells
  • • Hurthle cell tumors
  • • Option D: Ionizing radiation in early decades is a major risk factor – While exposure to ionizing radiation is a known risk factor for thyroid carcinoma , it is not specifically tied to the pathogenesis of Hurthle cell tumors, which are a variant of follicular carcinoma.
  • • Option D:
  • • Ionizing radiation in early decades is a major risk factor
  • • exposure to ionizing radiation
  • • risk factor
  • • thyroid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hurthle cell tumors are a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma , which are characterized by distinctive large cells with abundant granular cytoplasm and are encapsulated . They differ from papillary and medullary thyroid carcinomas both in terms of their origin and histological appearance.
  • ➤ Hurthle cell tumors
  • ➤ variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ distinctive large cells
  • ➤ abundant granular cytoplasm
  • ➤ encapsulated
  • ➤ differ from papillary
  • ➤ medullary thyroid carcinomas
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1089
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1089

questions.text: About papillary carcinoma of thyroid, all are true except:
questions.correct_answer: C. Early metastasis with poor prognosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Early metastasis with poor prognosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Prognosis better: This is true . Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid generally has an excellent prognosis, especially when diagnosed early and in younger patients.
  • • Option A:
  • • Prognosis better:
  • • true
  • • Option B: Psammoma body present in 50% cases: Psammoma bodies are calcifications that are often found in papillary thyroid carcinoma but may not be present in as many as 50% of cases.
  • • Option B:
  • • Psammoma body present in 50% cases:
  • • Option D: Spreads by the lymphatic route: This is true . Papillary thyroid carcinoma commonly spreads to regional lymph nodes via lymphatics.
  • • Option D:
  • • Spreads by the lymphatic route:
  • • true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid typically has a favorable prognosis , even with early lymphatic spread , contrasting with other cancers where early metastasis often correlates with a poor prognosis .
  • ➤ Papillary carcinoma
  • ➤ thyroid
  • ➤ favorable prognosis
  • ➤ early lymphatic spread
  • ➤ contrasting
  • ➤ cancers
  • ➤ early metastasis
  • ➤ poor prognosis
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1086
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1086

questions.text: A 51-year-old man Sonu with a history of recurrent calcium-containing renal stones presents to the emergency room with excruciating flank pain and blood in the urine. This patient is likely to have which of the following underlying disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperparathyroidism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Anemia of chronic disease – This condition is associated with long-standing , chronic illnesses that lead to alterations in iron metabolism and erythropoiesis but is not directly related to calcium stone formation.
  • • Option A:
  • • Anemia of chronic disease
  • • long-standing
  • • chronic illnesses
  • • alterations in iron metabolism
  • • erythropoiesis
  • • Option B: Chronic Proteus infection – While Proteus bacteria can increase the risk for struvite stone formation due to urease production , it is not typically associated with calcium stone formation.
  • • Option B:
  • • Chronic Proteus infection
  • • Proteus bacteria
  • • increase the risk for struvite stone formation
  • • urease production
  • • Option D: Hyperaldosteronism – This condition leads to hypertension and hypokalemia due to excess aldosterone and is not typically associated with calcium-containing renal stone disease.
  • • Option D:
  • • Hyperaldosteronism
  • • hypertension
  • • hypokalemia
  • • excess aldosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent calcium-containing renal stones may suggest an underlying disorder of calcium metabolism, such as hyperparathyroidism , due to its association with increased PTH levels , hypercalcemia , and hypercalciuria .
  • ➤ Recurrent calcium-containing renal stones
  • ➤ underlying disorder of calcium metabolism,
  • ➤ hyperparathyroidism
  • ➤ increased PTH levels
  • ➤ hypercalcemia
  • ➤ hypercalciuria
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 9/e p1103
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 9/e p1103

questions.text: Most common thyroid cancer after radiation exposure is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Papillary cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: Medullary cancer: Medullary thyroid cancer arises from parafollicular C-cells and is typically associated with genetic mutations in the RET proto-oncogene , not with radiation exposure.
  • • Option B:
  • • Medullary cancer:
  • • arises from parafollicular C-cells
  • • genetic mutations in the RET proto-oncogene
  • • Option C: Follicular cancer: While not associated with radiation exposure , the incidence of follicular carcinoma is higher in areas with iodine deficiency.
  • • Option C:
  • • Follicular cancer:
  • • not
  • • radiation exposure
  • • Option D: Anaplastic cancer: Anaplastic thyroid cancer is a rare and aggressive form of thyroid cancer that generally occurs in the elderly population and is not associated with radiation exposure.
  • • Option D:
  • • Anaplastic cancer:
  • • rare and aggressive form of thyroid cancer
  • • occurs in the elderly population

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer associated with childhood exposure to ionizing radiation , which can significantly increase the risk of this cancer .
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ most common thyroid cancer
  • ➤ childhood exposure
  • ➤ ionizing radiation
  • ➤ increase the risk of this cancer
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1086
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1086

questions.text: Orphan Annie eye nuclei appearance is characteristic of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Papillary carcinoma thyroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei is a distinctive cytological feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid , which is important for diagnosis and distinguishing it from other neoplasms.
  • ➤ 'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei
  • ➤ distinctive cytological feature
  • ➤ papillary carcinoma
  • ➤ thyroid
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1087
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1087

questions.text: The laboratory screening test which suggests normal thyroid function is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TSH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: Free T4: Free T4 measurement reflects the biologically active portion of thyroxine and can be normal in early or mild forms of thyroid dysfunction .
  • • Option B:
  • • Free T4:
  • • Free T4 measurement reflects
  • • biologically active portion of thyroxine
  • • normal in early or mild forms
  • • thyroid dysfunction
  • • Option C: T3: Total T3 levels can be affected by factors that influence binding proteins and are not the first line of screening; they are more helpful in diagnosing hyperthyroidism or in certain clinical situations like T3 toxicosis.
  • • Option C:
  • • T3:
  • • affected by factors
  • • influence binding proteins
  • • not the first line of screening;
  • • Option D: Free T3: Similar to T3, Free T3 is not the first line of screening but rather used for specific clinical indications and is less commonly measured than TSH or Free T4.
  • • Option D: Free T3:
  • • Free T3 is not the first line of screening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TSH is the most sensitive initial screening test for evaluating thyroid function because it reflects the pituitary's response to the serum concentration of free thyroid hormones , particularly free T4.
  • ➤ TSH
  • ➤ most sensitive initial screening test
  • ➤ evaluating thyroid function
  • ➤ reflects the pituitary's response
  • ➤ serum concentration
  • ➤ free thyroid hormones
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1083
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1083

questions.text: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with which of the following syndrome:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MEN II

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: MEN I – Incorrect. MEN I typically involves tumors of the parathyroid glands , pituitary gland , and pancreas , not medullary thyroid carcinoma.
  • • Option A:
  • • MEN I – Incorrect.
  • • tumors of the parathyroid glands
  • • pituitary gland
  • • pancreas
  • • Option C: Li-Fraumeni syndrome – Incorrect. This is a hereditary cancer syndrome associated with a variety of cancers , including sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors, but not specifically medullary thyroid carcinoma.
  • • Option C:
  • • Li-Fraumeni syndrome – Incorrect.
  • • hereditary cancer syndrome
  • • variety of cancers
  • • Option D: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis – Incorrect. This is an autoimmune disease of the thyroid gland and is not directly associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma , although thyroid cancer can occur more frequently in the setting of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • • Option D:
  • • Hashimoto’s thyroiditis – Incorrect.
  • • autoimmune disease
  • • thyroid gland
  • • medullary thyroid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma is commonly associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II (MEN II), which includes two subtypes , MEN IIA and MEN IIB , both characterized by the occurrence of medullary thyroid carcinoma and p heochromocytomas . MEN IIA also includes parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia.
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II
  • ➤ two subtypes
  • ➤ MEN IIA
  • ➤ MEN IIB
  • ➤ occurrence of medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ heochromocytomas
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1129
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1129

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a family history of endocrine neoplasia presents with a thyroid nodule. Histological examination of the nodule after fine-needle aspiration biopsy reveals amyloid deposition. Which of the following types of thyroid carcinoma is the woman most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medullary

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma: This is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterized by branching papillae and often presents with psammoma bodies . It is not typically associated with amyloid deposition.
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma:
  • • most common type of thyroid cancer
  • • branching papillae
  • • psammoma bodies
  • • Option B: Follicular carcinoma : It does not characteristically involve amyloid deposition .
  • • Option B: Follicular carcinoma
  • • not
  • • involve amyloid deposition
  • • Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma: This is a highly aggressive and undifferentiated form of thyroid cancer . Amyloid is not a feature of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.
  • • Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma:
  • • highly aggressive
  • • undifferentiated form of thyroid cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma is unique among thyroid cancers as it originates from parafollicular C-cells and is associated with amyloid deposition within the tumor , which can be identified histologically. This type of carcinoma can occur sporadically or as part of the multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 syndromes.
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ unique
  • ➤ thyroid cancers
  • ➤ originates from parafollicular C-cells
  • ➤ amyloid deposition
  • ➤ tumor
  • ➤ type of carcinoma
  • ➤ sporadically
  • ➤ part of the multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 syndromes.
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1091
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1091

questions.text: Which is not seen in MEN I:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I (MEN I) is characterized by the presence of tumors in parathyroid glands , anterior pituitary, and pancreatic islets , and does not commonly include medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is associated with MEN II.
  • ➤ Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I
  • ➤ presence of tumors in parathyroid glands
  • ➤ anterior pituitary,
  • ➤ pancreatic islets
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1091
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th 1091

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed, and the pathologist reports that the distinction between a benign and a malignant lesion cannot be made with certainty. Which type of thyroid nodule is most notorious for requiring histologic examination beyond FNAC to establish a definitive diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Follicular carcinoma of thyroid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid : Papillary carcinoma typically shows distinctive nuclear features on FNAC which are usually diagnostic, making it sufficient for diagnosis.
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid
  • • distinctive nuclear features on FNAC
  • • Option B: Carcinoma breast : FNAC can be diagnostic for breast carcinoma, showing malignant cells , but a core biopsy is often preferred for additional architectural and immunohistochemical information.
  • • Option B: Carcinoma breast
  • • diagnostic for breast carcinoma,
  • • malignant cells
  • • Option C: Adenocarcinoma lung : While FNAC can suggest adenocarcinoma of the lung by demonstrating malignant glandular cells, a core biopsy is usually required for complete characterization.
  • • Option C: Adenocarcinoma lung
  • • FNAC
  • • adenocarcinoma of the lung
  • • malignant glandular cells,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While FNAC can suggest follicular neoplasm , it cannot differentiate follicular carcinoma from follicular adenoma as the latter requires the identification of capsular or vascular invasion, which necessitates histological examination of the entire surgical specimen.
  • ➤ FNAC
  • ➤ follicular neoplasm
  • ➤ cannot differentiate follicular carcinoma
  • ➤ follicular adenoma
  • ➤ latter requires the identification of capsular
  • ➤ vascular invasion,
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1089
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1089

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with a history of a progressively enlarging neck mass over the past several years. She reports no symptoms of dysphagia, dyspnea, or hoarseness. Physical examination reveals a palpable, non-tender, firm mass in the anterior neck consistent with a long-standing goitre. Which malignancy develops in long standing goitre?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Follicular carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma: This is the most common thyroid malignancy and can occur with or without a preceding goiter . It has a distinctive histological appearance but is not particularly associated with iodine deficiency or long-standing goiters.
  • • Option A: Papillary carcinoma:
  • • most common thyroid malignancy
  • • with or without a preceding goiter
  • • Option C: Medullary carcinoma: This type of cancer arises from parafollicular C cells producing calcitonin and is commonly associated with genetic syndromes like MEN 2, rather than long-standing goiters.
  • • Option C: Medullary carcinoma:
  • • cancer arises from parafollicular C cells
  • • calcitonin
  • • genetic syndromes like MEN 2,
  • • Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma: This is a very aggressive form of thyroid cancer that can arise de novo or from existing well-differentiated tumors but isn't specifically linked to long-standing goiters.
  • • Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma:
  • • very aggressive form of thyroid cancer
  • • arise de novo
  • • existing well-differentiated tumors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with iodine deficiency and is more likely to develop in the setting of a long-standing goiter . This malignancy is notorious for hematogenous spread and requires thorough histological examination to differentiate it from benign conditions.
  • ➤ thyroid is associated with iodine deficiency
  • ➤ develop in the setting of a long-standing goiter
  • ➤ malignancy
  • ➤ notorious for hematogenous spread
  • ➤ histological examination
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1089
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1089

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hypercalcemia, peptic ulcer disease, and a pituitary mass on imaging. Given these clinical features, which of the following conditions is least likely to be part of the patient's underlying syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior pituitary tumors

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Foregut carcinoid - Foregut carcinoids (including those found in the thymus, lung, and stomach) are part of the spectrum of MEN-1 syndrome , although less common compared to other manifestations.
  • • Option A: Foregut carcinoid
  • • part of the spectrum of MEN-1 syndrome
  • • Option C: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors - These tumors are a hallmark of MEN-1 and can produce a variety of symptoms depending on the hormone they secrete (e.g., gastrin, insulin).
  • • Option C: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
  • • hallmark of MEN-1
  • • produce a variety of symptoms
  • • hormone they secrete
  • • Option D: Parathyroid hyperplasia - Primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid hyperplasia is the most common feature of MEN-1 syndrome, causing hypercalcemia.
  • • Option D: Parathyroid hyperplasia
  • • Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • • parathyroid hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MEN-1 syndrome, also known as Wermer syndrome, is characterized by anterior pituitary tumors, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors , and parathyroid hyperplasia, but not by tumors of the posterior pituitary.
  • ➤ MEN-1 syndrome,
  • ➤ Wermer syndrome,
  • ➤ anterior pituitary tumors,
  • ➤ pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
  • ➤ parathyroid hyperplasia,
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1129
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1129

questions.text: All of the following are feature of granulomatous thyroiditis except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Painless

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: In the initial phase of granulomatous (subacute) thyroiditis , there may be a transient hyperthyroid phase due to the inflammatory destruction of thyroid follicles leading to the release of preformed thyroid hormones into circulation .
  • • Option A:
  • • initial phase of granulomatous
  • • thyroiditis
  • • transient hyperthyroid phase
  • • inflammatory destruction of thyroid follicles
  • • release of preformed thyroid hormones into circulation
  • • Option B: Following the hyperthyroid phase of granulomatous thyroiditis, there is a hypothyroid phase as the damaged thyroid may be temporarily unable to produce sufficient hormones . This is usually self-limited, and normal thyroid function often returns, but some patients may develop permanent hypothyroidism.
  • • Option B:
  • • hyperthyroid phase
  • • granulomatous thyroiditis,
  • • hypothyroid phase
  • • damaged thyroid
  • • temporarily unable to produce sufficient hormones
  • • Option D: Granulomatous thyroiditis is characterized histologically by granuloma formation with giant cells . These multinucleated giant cells are part of the body's response to inflammation and are involved in the degradation of thyroglobulin, which is released during the follicular destruction.
  • • Option D:
  • • Granulomatous thyroiditis
  • • histologically
  • • granuloma formation with giant cells
  • • multinucleated giant cells
  • • body's response to inflammation
  • • degradation of thyroglobulin,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granulomatous thyroiditis is the most common cause of thyroid pain, not a painless condition.
  • ➤ Granulomatous thyroiditis
  • ➤ thyroid pain,
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1093
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th 1093

questions.text: Brown tumour is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brown tumors are associated with hyperparathyroidism and represent a severe manifestation of osteitis fibrosa cystica , where excessive bone resorption leads to fibrous and cystic bone changes .
  • ➤ Brown tumors
  • ➤ hyperparathyroidism
  • ➤ represent a severe manifestation
  • ➤ osteitis fibrosa cystica
  • ➤ excessive bone resorption
  • ➤ fibrous
  • ➤ cystic bone changes

questions.text: Most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Exogenous corticosteroids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: A pituitary adenoma that secretes adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) can cause Cushing's disease , which is a subset of Cushing's syndrome. This is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing's syndrome , but overall less common than the exogenous form caused by taking corticosteroid medications.
  • • Option B:
  • • pituitary adenoma
  • • secretes adrenocorticotropic hormone
  • • Cushing's disease
  • • common cause of endogenous Cushing's syndrome
  • • Option C: An adrenal adenoma is a benign tumor of the adrenal gland that can autonomously secrete cortisol . It's a less common cause of Cushing's syndrome compared to exogenous steroid use and pituitary tumors but should be considered, especially when ACTH levels are low.
  • • Option C:
  • • adrenal adenoma
  • • benign tumor
  • • adrenal gland
  • • autonomously secrete cortisol
  • • less common cause of Cushing's syndrome
  • • exogenous steroid use
  • • pituitary tumors
  • • Option D: Adrenal carcinomas are rare but can also cause Cushing's syndrome by secreting excessive amounts of cortisol . They are more aggressive than adenomas and can be associated with a worse prognosis.
  • • Option D:
  • • Adrenal carcinomas
  • • rare
  • • cause Cushing's syndrome
  • • secreting excessive amounts of cortisol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exogenous corticosteroids are the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome , primarily due to the widespread use of corticosteroid medications for a variety of medical conditions.
  • ➤ Exogenous corticosteroids
  • ➤ most common cause of Cushing's syndrome
  • ➤ widespread use of corticosteroid medications
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1115
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1115

questions.text: Submucosal neuroma is associated with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MEN II B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I (MEN I) is a syndrome characterized by the presence of tumors in the parathyroid glands , pancreatic islet cells , and the anterior pituitary gland . Submucosal neuromas are not typically associated with MEN I.
  • • Option A: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I (MEN I)
  • • syndrome
  • • presence of tumors
  • • parathyroid glands
  • • pancreatic islet cells
  • • anterior pituitary gland
  • • Option B: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II A (MEN II A) is a syndrome that includes medullary thyroid carcinoma , pheochromocytoma , and primary hyperparathyroidism . It does not typically present with submucosal neuromas.
  • • Option B: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II A (MEN II A)
  • • syndrome
  • • includes medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • • pheochromocytoma
  • • primary hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Submucosal neuromas are associated with MEN II B and can contribute to the diagnosis of this syndrome.
  • ➤ Submucosal neuromas
  • ➤ MEN II B
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th 1130
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th 1130

questions.text: Most common site of pheochromocytoma after adrenal gland is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Organs of Zuckerkandl

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: The hilum of the kidney is an area where the renal artery enters and the renal vein and ureter exit . While it is close to the adrenal glands , it is not a common site for extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas , which are tumors that arise from chromaffin cells typically found in the adrenal medulla.
  • • Option A:
  • • hilum of the kidney
  • • area where the renal artery enters
  • • renal vein and ureter exit
  • • close to the adrenal glands
  • • not a common site for extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas
  • • Option C: While chromaffin tissue can be found along the sympathetic chain in the neck , pheochromocytomas are not commonly found in this location.
  • • Option C:
  • • chromaffin tissue
  • • found along
  • • sympathetic chain in the neck
  • • Option D: Pheochromocytomas can occur in the urinary bladder , but it is an uncommon site . When they do occur in this location, they can cause symptoms such as hypertension, palpitations, and headache during micturition.
  • • Option D:
  • • Pheochromocytomas
  • • urinary bladder
  • • uncommon site

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Organs of Zuckerkandl are the most common extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma .
  • ➤ Organs of Zuckerkandl
  • ➤ most common extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1130
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1130

questions.text: True about adrenal pheochromocytoma is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral in 10% of cases

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Adrenal pheochromocytomas are typically chromaffin positive , meaning they stain positively for chromaffin , which is indicative of catecholamine-secreting cells . These tumors arise from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla.
  • • Option A:
  • • Adrenal pheochromocytomas
  • • chromaffin positive
  • • stain positively for chromaffin
  • • catecholamine-secreting cells
  • • Option B: While pheochromocytomas can be malignant , most are benign . The malignancy rate is estimated to be about 10% in adrenal pheochromocytomas. Malignancy is usually determined by the presence of metastasis rather than histological features.
  • • Option B:
  • • pheochromocytomas can be malignant
  • • benign
  • • malignancy rate
  • • about 10% in adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • • Option D: This statement is incorrect because unilateral pheochromocytomas are much more common than 10%. The majority of pheochromocytomas are unilateral.
  • • Option D:
  • • unilateral pheochromocytomas
  • • much more common than 10%.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While most adrenal pheochromocytomas are benign and unilateral, they can be bilateral in 10% of cases , especially in hereditary syndromes .
  • ➤ adrenal pheochromocytomas are benign and unilateral,
  • ➤ bilateral in 10% of cases
  • ➤ hereditary syndromes
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1127
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1127

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Physical examination reveals elevated blood pressure and a palpable abdominal mass. Which of the following tumors is most likely to exhibit the "rule of 10" characteristic?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pheochromocytoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: Oncocytomas are benign renal epithelial tumors that typically do not follow the "rule of 10s". They are usually asymptomatic and are often found incidentally during imaging for other conditions.
  • • Option B:
  • • Oncocytomas
  • • benign renal epithelial tumors
  • • do not follow the "rule of 10s".
  • • Option C: Lymphomas are cancers of the lymphatic system and do not follow the "rule of 10s". They have various subtypes with differing presentations and prognoses.
  • • Option C:
  • • Lymphomas
  • • cancers of the lymphatic system
  • • do not follow the "rule of 10s".
  • • Option D: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults and does not adhere to the "rule of 10s". RCC has different subtypes with varying clinical behaviors and genetic associations.
  • • Option D: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
  • • most common type of kidney cancer
  • • adults

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pheochromocytoma is classically described by the "rule of 10s", which can be helpful in remembering the characteristics of this tumor for diagnosis and management decisions .
  • ➤ Pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ "rule of 10s",
  • ➤ helpful in remembering
  • ➤ tumor for diagnosis
  • ➤ management decisions
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th 1127
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th 1127

questions.text: Which one of the following is not seen in pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diarrhea

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Hypertension is a hallmark sign of pheochromocytoma and can be sustained or paroxysmal due to episodic catecholamine secretion by the tumor.
  • • Option A:
  • • Hypertension
  • • hallmark sign of pheochromocytoma
  • • Option B: Episodic palpitations are a common symptom of pheochromocytoma due to episodic release of catecholamines , particularly norepinephrine , which stimulates the heart and causes increased contractility and heart rate.
  • • Option B: Episodic palpitations
  • • common symptom of pheochromocytoma
  • • episodic release of catecholamines
  • • norepinephrine
  • • Option C: Weight loss is frequently seen in pheochromocytoma patients . The excess catecholamines can increase metabolism and cause a hyperadrenergic state , leading to weight loss even in the presence of a good appetite.
  • • Option C: Weight loss
  • • seen in pheochromocytoma patients
  • • excess catecholamines
  • • increase metabolism
  • • hyperadrenergic state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While hypertension , episodic palpitations , and weight loss are common in pheochromocytoma , diarrhea is not typically associated with this condition.
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ episodic palpitations
  • ➤ weight loss
  • ➤ pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1127
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1127

questions.text: Mitotic figures and giant cells are seen in which of the following tumor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Benign and malignant pheochromocytoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A: Thyroid cancers can indeed present with mitotic figures , especially in more aggressive forms such as anaplastic thyroid carcinoma . However, giant cells are particularly characteristic of certain inflammatory conditions such as subacute thyroiditis, rather than thyroid neoplasms.
  • • Option A:
  • • Thyroid cancers
  • • present with mitotic figures
  • • more aggressive forms
  • • anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
  • • Option C: Benign and malignant liver tumors \ such as hepatocellular carcinoma can show mitotic figures , indicating a high proliferative rate . However, giant cells are more typical of specific liver pathologies such as giant cell hepatitis, not necessarily of benign or malignant liver tumors.
  • • Option C:
  • • Benign and malignant liver tumors
  • • hepatocellular carcinoma
  • • show mitotic figures
  • • high proliferative rate
  • • Option D: In renal tumors , mitotic figures are also indicative of a higher grade of malignancy , especially in clear cell renal carcinoma . Giant cells are not a characteristic feature of common benign or malignant renal tumors.
  • • Option D:
  • • renal tumors
  • • mitotic figures
  • • higher grade of malignancy
  • • clear cell renal carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The histological presence of mitotic figures and giant cells in pheochromocytomas is not indicative of malignancy ; instead, malignancy is confirmed by the presence of metastatic disease .
  • ➤ histological presence
  • ➤ mitotic figures
  • ➤ giant cells in pheochromocytomas
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ malignancy
  • ➤ malignancy
  • ➤ presence of metastatic disease
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1127
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1127

questions.text: Homer wright rosettes are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neuroblastoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B: Also known as Wilms' tumor , nephroblastoma is a kidney tumor usually found in children . It can show other types of rosette formations, but not typically Homer Wright rosettes.
  • • Option B:
  • • Wilms' tumor
  • • nephroblastoma
  • • kidney tumor
  • • found in children
  • • Option C: Hepatoma , or hepatocellular carcinoma , is a liver tumor and does not feature the presence of Homer Wright rosettes. Its pathology is markedly different from that of neuroblastic tumors.
  • • Option C:
  • • Hepatoma
  • • hepatocellular carcinoma
  • • liver tumor
  • • Option D: Ependymomas are glial cell tumors that can form rosettes known as perivascular rosettes or ependymal rosettes , which are distinct from Homer Wright rosettes.
  • • Option D:
  • • Ependymomas
  • • glial cell tumors
  • • form rosettes
  • • perivascular rosettes
  • • ependymal rosettes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Homer wright rosettes are seen in Neuroblastoma.
  • ➤ Homer wright rosettes
  • ➤ Neuroblastoma.
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 480
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 480

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the “rule of 10” in pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 10% are symptomatic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: In the context of pheochromocytoma , approximately 10% of tumors can be found bilaterally , often associated with hereditary conditions such as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia types 2A and 2B , von Hippel-Lindau disease , and neurofibromatosis type 1 .
  • • Option A:
  • • pheochromocytoma
  • • approximately 10% of tumors
  • • bilaterally
  • • hereditary conditions
  • • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia types 2A
  • • 2B
  • • von Hippel-Lindau disease
  • • neurofibromatosis type 1
  • • Option B: Pheochromocytomas are usually benign , but about 10% can be malignant . Malignancy is determined by the presence of metastases rather than the histological appearance of the primary tumor.
  • • Option B:
  • • Pheochromocytomas
  • • benign
  • • 10% can be malignant
  • • Option C: Around 10% of pheochromocytomas are located outside of the adrenal glands , commonly in the abdomen in locations like the organ of Zuckerkandl . These are termed paragangliomas.
  • • Option C:
  • • 10% of pheochromocytomas
  • • located outside of the adrenal glands
  • • abdomen
  • • organ of Zuckerkandl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "rule of 10" in pheochromocytoma refers to the observation that approximately:
  • ➤ "rule of 10"
  • ➤ pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ observation
  • ➤ 10% of pheochromocytomas are extra-adrenal. 10% of pheochromocytomas are bilateral, affecting both adrenal glands. 10% of pheochromocytomas are malignant.
  • ➤ 10% of pheochromocytomas are extra-adrenal.
  • ➤ 10% of pheochromocytomas are bilateral, affecting both adrenal glands.
  • ➤ 10% of pheochromocytomas are malignant.
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1127
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1127

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Sipple Syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperthyroidism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Pheochromocytoma is a characteristic feature of MEN 2A and presents as a catecholamine-secreting tumor typically originating in the adrenal medulla.
  • • Option A:
  • • Pheochromocytoma
  • • feature of MEN 2A
  • • catecholamine-secreting tumor
  • • Option B: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor of the thyroid and a principal feature of MEN 2A . It arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland and secretes calcitonin.
  • • Option B:
  • • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • • neuroendocrine tumor
  • • thyroid
  • • principal feature of MEN 2A
  • • Option D: Primary hyperparathyroidism is part of the MEN 2A syndrome and is due to hyperplasia or adenoma of the parathyroid glands leading to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).
  • • Option D:
  • • Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • • part of the MEN 2A syndrome
  • • due to hyperplasia
  • • adenoma of the parathyroid glands
  • • excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While pheochromocytoma , medullary thyroid carcinoma , and hyperparathyroidism are part of the Sipple syndrome , hyperthyroidism is not.
  • ➤ pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ hyperparathyroidism
  • ➤ Sipple syndrome
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1130
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1130
